title: Lesson 3: Newton's First Law of Motion
content:
Lesson 3: Newton's First Law of Motion

The Law of Inertia: Why Things Keep Doing What They're Doing

Have you ever seen the magic trick where someone yanks a tablecloth from under a pile of dishes, and the dishes stay put? It's not magic, it's physics!

This lesson explains the secret behind this trick—a fundamental rule of the universe that objects are "lazy" and resist change.

What is Newton's First Law of Motion?

Newton's First Law of Motion, also known as the Law of Inertia, describes how objects behave when left alone. The law is stated as:

"An object remains in a state of rest or of uniform motion in a straight line unless compelled to change that state by an applied unbalanced force."

Let's break that down into two simple parts:

  • Part 1: An object that isn't moving (at rest) will stay that way forever. A football on the grass won't move until something (like a foot) applies an unbalanced force to it.
  • Part 2: An object that is moving will keep moving forever at the same speed and in the same direction. This is harder to see on Earth because of friction, but in space, a pushed object will drift forever.

Inertia: The Resistance to Change

The First Law tells us that all objects have a built-in property called inertia. Inertia is the natural tendency of an object to resist any change in its state of motion.

Think of it as an object's "stubbornness" or "laziness":

  • 

    If it's resting, its inertia wants it to stay resting.

  • 

    If it's moving, its inertia wants it to keep moving exactly as it is.

An unbalanced force is the only thing that can overcome an object's inertia and force it to change what it's doing.

Inertia in Your Daily Life

1. The Bus Ride Experience

When a moving bus suddenly stops, your body continues to move forward. This is because your body has inertia of motion. The bus stopped, but your body tried to keep moving forward, causing you to lurch.

Conversely, when a bus starts suddenly, you feel thrown backwards. This is because your body was at rest and its inertia tried to keep it at rest, while the bus moved forward from under you.

2. The Coin and Card Trick

If you place a coin on a stiff card over a glass and flick the card away quickly, the coin drops straight into the glass. Why?

The coin was at rest and had inertia of rest. The flicking force acted on the card, but not on the coin. The coin's inertia made it resist moving, so it stayed in place and fell downwards due to gravity once the card was gone.

Lesson 3 at a Glance: The Law of Inertia

If an object is AT REST...

...it will stay at rest.

If an object is IN MOTION...

...it will stay in motion (at a constant speed and direction).

This is true ONLY IF the net force is ZERO.

An UNBALANCED FORCE is the only thing that can change an object's state of motion.
questions:
Lesson 3: Questions & Answers

1. What is the common name for Newton's First Law of Motion, and what fundamental property of objects does it describe?

Step 1: Recall the nickname. Newton's First Law is famously known by another name that describes the "laziness" of objects.

Step 2: Identify the property. This "laziness" or resistance to change is the key property.

It is commonly called the Law of Inertia. It describes the property of Inertia, which is the natural tendency of any object to resist a change in its state of motion.

2. When you shake a mango tree branch vigorously, the ripe mangoes fall down. Explain this phenomenon using the concept of inertia.

Step 1: Identify the initial states. Before shaking, both the branch and the mangoes are in a state of rest. They have inertia of rest.

Step 2: Identify the action. When you shake the branch, you apply an unbalanced force to the branch, setting it into motion.

Step 3: Consider the mangoes. The force is not directly applied to the mangoes. Due to their inertia of rest, the mangoes try to remain where they were (at rest). The branch moves away, but the mangoes stay put, causing them to detach from the stem and fall due to gravity.

The branches are set into motion, but the mangoes resist this motion due to their inertia, causing them to break off and fall.

3. According to Newton's First Law, what is required to change an object's state of motion?

Step 1: Remember the law states an object will continue its state of rest or uniform motion *unless* something acts on it.

Step 2: That "something" cannot be a balanced force, because balanced forces cause no change in motion.

An unbalanced force is required to change an object's state of motion.

4. You are a passenger in a car. The driver makes a sudden, sharp right turn. In which direction do you feel 'thrown', and why? Is there a real force pushing you in that direction?

Step 1: What you feel. When the car turns right, you feel thrown to the left.

Step 2: The real motion. Before the turn, your body was moving straight ahead. Due to inertia of motion, your body tries to continue moving in that same straight line.

Step 3: The 'push'. As the car turns right, the side of the car (the door) literally pushes into you on your right side to make you turn with it. The sensation of being 'thrown left' is actually your body trying to go straight while the car turns right from under you.

There is no real force pushing you to the left. It's simply your body's inertia resisting the change in direction.

5. Explain the purpose of a car's seatbelt using the Law of Inertia.

Step 1: Motion. When a car is moving, you and the car are both in a state of motion. You both have inertia of motion.

Step 2: Sudden Stop. If the car stops suddenly (e.g., in a collision), the brakes apply an unbalanced force to the car, stopping it. However, no such force is applied to your body.

Step 3: Your Body's Inertia. Due to inertia, your body tries to continue moving forward at the same speed it was travelling, which would cause you to hit the dashboard or windshield.

Step 4: The Seatbelt's Role. The seatbelt is designed to apply a large, unbalanced stopping force to your body, forcing you to slow down along with the car and preventing injury.

6. What did Galileo conclude from his experiments with inclined planes that helped Newton form his first law?

Galileo's experiments led to a revolutionary idea:

  • He observed a marble rolling down one slope would try to roll up another to the same height.
  • He reasoned that if the second slope were made horizontal and frictionless, the marble would roll forever, trying to reach its original height.
  • From this, he concluded that an object does not need a force to keep it in uniform motion. An object moves with a constant velocity when the net force on it is zero.

7. True or False: The 'natural state' of an object is to be at rest.

False.

Explanation: For centuries, people believed this was true because on Earth, moving objects always eventually stop due to friction. However, Galileo and Newton showed that this is incorrect. An object's 'natural state' is to simply maintain its current state of motion. Both being at rest and moving with a constant velocity are equally natural states.

8. In Activity 8.1 (the carom coins), a sharp hit to the bottom coin makes it shoot out while the stack above falls vertically. How does this demonstrate inertia?

Step 1: The stack of coins is initially in a state of rest. They have inertia of rest.

Step 2: The sharp hit applies a large, sudden, unbalanced force to the bottom coin only.

Step 3: The coins in the stack above are not directly acted upon by this force. Due to their inertia, they resist the change and try to remain at rest in their original position.

Step 4: Once the bottom coin is gone, there is nothing supporting the stack, so it falls straight down due to gravity.

9. An object is travelling with a non-zero velocity. Is it possible for the net external force on it to be zero? If yes, state the condition.

Yes, it is possible.

Condition: According to Newton's First Law, an object will continue in its state of uniform motion if the net force is zero. This means the object must be travelling with a constant velocity (constant speed and constant direction). A car moving at a steady 60 km/h on a straight highway is an example where the forward engine force is balanced by the backward forces of friction and air resistance, making the net force zero.

10. Why is Newton's First Law a "qualitative" definition of force, not a "quantitative" one?

Step 1: Qualitative vs. Quantitative. 'Qualitative' describes the 'what' or 'quality' of something. 'Quantitative' describes the 'how much' or 'quantity'.

Step 2: What the First Law tells us. Newton's First Law tells us what a force does (it changes motion) and defines inertia. It explains the concept.

Step 3: What it doesn't tell us. It does not give us a way to measure or calculate the exact value of a force (e.g., in Newtons). That is the job of Newton's Second Law.

The First Law defines the concept of force and inertia (quality) but does not provide a formula to measure it (quantity).
exercises:
Lesson 3: Exercises

1. Fill in the Blanks with Inertia

a) An object's natural resistance to a change in its state of rest or motion is called ________.

b) When a bus starts suddenly, you feel thrown backwards due to inertia of ________.

c) When a bus stops suddenly, you lurch forwards due to inertia of ________.

Answers:

  • a) An object's natural resistance to a change in its state of rest or motion is called inertia.
  • b) When a bus starts suddenly, you feel thrown backwards due to inertia of rest.
  • c) When a bus stops suddenly, you lurch forwards due to inertia of motion.

2. Scenario Analysis: The Dusty Carpet

When a hanging carpet is beaten with a stick, dust particles fly out of it. Explain this observation using the concept of inertia.

Step 1: Initial State. Both the carpet and the dust particles within it are at rest. They have inertia of rest.
Step 2: Apply Force. The stick applies a sudden, unbalanced force to the carpet, causing the carpet to move backwards quickly.
Step 3: Inertia of Dust. The force is not applied to the dust particles. Due to their inertia of rest, they resist this change and tend to remain in their original position.
Step 4: Result. The carpet moves away, but the dust particles stay put, effectively "falling out" of the carpet.

3. What if...? The Astronaut's Wrench

An astronaut in deep space, far from any planets or stars, is moving along with her spaceship at a constant velocity. If she gently lets go of a wrench, what will the wrench do?

  • a) It will fall "down".
  • b) It will stop moving instantly.
  • c) It will continue to move alongside her at the same constant velocity.
  • d) It will move backwards, away from the spaceship.

Step 1: Analyze the situation. "Deep space" implies there is no significant gravity and no air friction. This means there are no external unbalanced forces.
Step 2: Apply Newton's First Law. The law states that an object in motion (the wrench) will stay in motion with the same velocity unless an unbalanced force acts on it.
Step 3: Evaluate the options. (a) is wrong because there is no "down". (b) is wrong because an unbalanced stopping force is needed. (d) is wrong because no force pushed it backward.

Correct Answer: c) It will continue to move alongside her at the same constant velocity.

4. Correct the Misconception

A friend tells you, "Inertia is the force that keeps things from stopping." Is this statement correct? If not, explain the error.

The statement is incorrect.

Explanation of the Error:

  • Inertia is not a force. It does not push or pull. It is a property of all matter.
  • Inertia is the resistance to a change in motion. It doesn't actively "keep" things moving; it simply describes the tendency of a moving object to continue its motion if no force interferes.

5. Which has more inertia?

For each pair, identify which object has more inertia and briefly explain why.

  • A five-rupee coin or a one-rupee coin?
  • An empty water bottle or the same bottle full of water?
  • A bicycle or a train?

The key principle is: More mass means more inertia. Inertia is a measure of mass.

  • A five-rupee coin has more inertia because it has more mass than a one-rupee coin.
  • The bottle full of water has more inertia because it has more mass than the empty bottle.
  • A train has more inertia because it has vastly more mass than a bicycle.

6. Thought Experiment: The Perfect World

Imagine a perfectly smooth horizontal floor with no air resistance. If you give a hockey puck a gentle push, what would its motion be like according to Newton's First Law?

Step 1: The gentle push is an unbalanced force that changes the puck's state from rest to motion.
Step 2: Once your hand is no longer touching it, there are no more horizontal forces acting on the puck (no push, no friction, no air resistance). The net force becomes zero.
Step 3: According to the First Law, with zero net force, the object will continue in its state of motion.

The puck would slide forever in a straight line at a constant speed.

7. Why Tie the Luggage?

Explain why it is dangerous not to tie down luggage on the roof of a bus, considering both when the bus starts and when it stops suddenly.

  • When the bus starts suddenly: The luggage is at rest and has inertia of rest. It will resist moving forward with the bus, causing it to slide off the back.
  • When the bus stops suddenly: The luggage is in motion and has inertia of motion. It will resist stopping with the bus, causing it to continue moving forward and fly off the front.

The rope provides the necessary unbalanced force to make the luggage accelerate and decelerate along with the bus.

8. Which Law Applies?

When a moving car brakes to a stop, you fall in the forward direction. Which law of motion explains this phenomenon?

This phenomenon is explained by Newton's First Law of Motion (The Law of Inertia). Your body, due to its inertia of motion, tries to continue moving forward even after the car has stopped.
intros:
Lesson 3: Newton's First Law of Motion

Why do objects like to keep doing what they're doing? Discover the fundamental "laziness" of the universe that governs everything from a sleeping cat to a speeding car.

Intro 1: The Lazy Object

Why do you lurch forward when a bus suddenly stops? Is something pushing you?

Objects in our universe are a bit "lazy." They have a natural tendency to keep doing whatever they're already doing. A ball at rest will stay at rest forever unless you kick it. This resistance to changing their state of motion is called Inertia.

When the bus you're on is moving, your body is also moving at the same speed. If the driver suddenly hits the brakes, the bus stops, but your body, due to its inertia, tries to continue moving forward. That's why you lurch forward! Nothing is pushing you; your body is just trying to continue its motion. This is the core idea of Newton's First Law.

Inertia: An object's natural resistance to any change in its motion.

Intro 2: The Magic Trick

How can a magician pull a tablecloth from under a pile of dishes without them falling? Is it really magic?

INERTIA. THE "MAGIC"

What looks like magic is actually a brilliant demonstration of Newton's First Law! The law states that an object at rest will stay at rest unless an unbalanced force acts on it. The dishes are at rest and, because they have mass, they have inertia—a strong desire to remain at rest.

When the tablecloth is yanked away very quickly, there is very little time for the force of friction to act on the dishes and make them move. The dishes' own inertia is so strong that it resists the small, quick pull from the cloth. As a result, they stay put and land safely on the table. The same principle is at work when you flick a card from under a coin.

It's not magic, it's inertia in action!

Intro 3: The Astronaut's Push

If an astronaut in deep space gently pushes a satellite, will it ever stop moving?

On Earth, when you slide a box across the floor, it quickly stops because of friction. Friction is an unbalanced force that opposes motion. But what about in space, where there's no air and no ground to cause friction?

This is where the second part of Newton's First Law shines: an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. Since there are no unbalanced forces like friction in deep space, the pushed satellite will continue to drift away in a straight line, at a constant speed, potentially forever!

No unbalanced force means no change in motion, even if it's already moving.

Intro 4: The Galileo Ramp

If you roll a marble down a U-shaped ramp, it almost reaches the same height. What if the other side was less steep? What if it was completely flat?

Long before Newton, a scientist named Galileo Galilei thought about this exact problem. He noticed that a marble rolling down one ramp will try to roll up another ramp to its original height. If the second ramp is less steep, the marble has to travel a longer distance to get there.

Galileo then asked the crucial question: what if the second ramp wasn't a ramp at all, but a perfectly smooth, flat, horizontal surface? The marble would roll on and on forever, constantly trying to reach its original height, which it never could! This thought experiment led him to realize that an object doesn't need a force to keep it moving. It only needs a force to stop it (like friction). Newton built his first law on this powerful idea.

Motion is as natural as rest—it's only friction that makes us think otherwise.

Intro 5: The Stubborn Mule

Why is it easy to push an empty shopping cart but incredibly hard to push a full one, or a giant boulder?

All objects have inertia—they all resist changes in their motion. But some objects are more "stubborn" than others. An empty shopping cart has very little resistance, so a small push (an unbalanced force) is enough to get it moving.

A heavy boulder, on the other hand, has a huge amount of inertia. It strongly resists any attempt to change its state of rest. You need to apply a much, much larger unbalanced force to overcome its "stubbornness" and get it to move. This stubbornness, or inertia, is directly related to an object's mass.

More mass means more inertia. It's that simple.
summary:
Lesson 3: Summary

Newton's First Law (The Law of Inertia): Exam Quick Revision

Statement of the Law

"An object remains in a state of rest or of uniform motion in a straight line unless compelled to change that state by an applied unbalanced force."

Visualizing the Law of Inertia

What is Inertia?

Inertia is the natural tendency of an object to resist a change in its state of motion. It is a fundamental property of matter.

  • Inertia of Rest: Tendency to resist being set in motion.
  • Inertia of Motion: Tendency to resist being stopped or changing direction.

The "Unless..." Clause

The law only holds true when the net force is zero (forces are balanced).

An unbalanced force is the only thing that can overcome an object's inertia and cause it to accelerate (change its velocity).

Key Examples for Exams

Sudden Start/Stop in a Bus:

When a bus stops, your body continues forward due to inertia of motion. When it starts, your body is thrown back due to inertia of rest.

Beating a Carpet:

The carpet moves, but the dust particles stay at rest due to their inertia, causing them to separate from the carpet.

Coin and Card Trick:

The card is flicked away, but the coin's inertia of rest keeps it in place, so it drops into the glass below.
